title: Supply Chain Security

description.short: Secure dependencies, build tools, and CI/CD pipelines
description.medium: Review dependencies before installing, scan for vulnerabilities with SCA tools, generate SBOMs, use lock files, verify signatures, and protect your build pipeline from compromise
description.full: Supply chain security protects the dependencies, build tools, container images, CI/CD pipelines, and third-party components your application relies on. This covers dependency scanning (SCA), Software Bill of Materials (SBOM), lock files, license compliance, typosquatting defense, container security, code signing, SLSA framework, private registries, and responding to supply chain compromises like SolarWinds or Log4Shell.

why_it_matters: High-profile attacks target the supply chain (SolarWinds, Log4j, event-stream)
Dependencies can contain malware or vulnerabilities
Compromised build pipelines affect all downstream users
Compliance increasingly requires SBOM and provenance

objectives: Understand that dependencies are attack vectors
Use dependency scanning tools (Dependabot, Snyk, npm audit)
key_takeaways: Don't blindly install packages - review them first

objectives: Generate and use Software Bill of Materials (SBOM)
Set up comprehensive dependency scanning in CI/CD
Defend against typosquatting and malicious packages
key_takeaways: SBOM provides visibility into all components
Direct and transitive dependencies both pose risk
Container base images need security just like dependencies

objectives: Implement SLSA framework for build integrity
Use private registries with dependency firewall
Sign artifacts and verify provenance with Sigstore
Build incident response for supply chain compromises
key_takeaways: SLSA levels provide measurable supply chain security maturity
Code signing and provenance prevent tampering
Private registries with mirroring reduce external dependency risk
SBOM enables rapid impact analysis during incidents

frameworks_and_concepts: Software Bill of Materials (SBOM - CycloneDX, SPDX)
SLSA Framework (Supply-chain Levels for Software Artifacts)

estimated_time_to_implement.mid_depth: 2-4 weeks to implement SBOM generation and comprehensive scanning
estimated_time_to_implement.deep_water: 3-6 months for SLSA Level 2+, private registries, and signing

common_mistakes: Blindly updating all dependencies without testing
Trusting all packages in public registries
No SBOM or inventory of dependencies
success_metrics: Time to update vulnerable dependencies (< 7 days for critical)
Dependency freshness (% of deps within N versions of latest)
Vulnerability exposure window (time between CVE publish and patch)
Zero critical vulnerabilities from dependencies in production
when_to_prioritize: Building production systems with external dependencies
After major supply chain incidents (Log4j, etc.)
Open source projects with many users
when_to_deprioritize: Completely air-gapped systems with no external dependencies
Internal tools with no sensitive data and no internet access
